snippet: Leaked documents add new details to a secret body of law that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has developed since it began to broaden its role in 2001.
abstract: Documents leaked by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden add new details to the emerging public understanding of a secret body of law developed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court; documents show how the court evolved from its original task of approving wiretap requests to justifying activities like the bulk collection of data about Americans' emails and phone calls.

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and LAURA POITRAS
byline.contributor: Charlie Savage reported from Washington, and Laura Poitras from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: Leaked documents add new details to a secret body of law that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has developed since it began to broaden its role in 2001.

headline.main: How a Court Secretly Evolved, Extending U.S. Spies’ Reach
headline.print_headline: How a Court Secretly Evolved, Extending U.S. Spies’ Reach

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject
